Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Integrable systems in geometry and mathematical physics; July 13-17, 2020; Trieste, Italy
Award.AbstractNarration: The Conference Integrable Systems in Geometry and Mathematical Physics will be organized at SISSA, Trieste, Italy, July 13-17, 2020. It is a satellite event to the 8th European Congress of Mathematics: https://www.8ecm.si/program/satellite-events. The venue of the conference, SISSA is one of the leading European research universities, situated in Trieste, which is one of the most important scientific hubs in Italy. The meeting will focus on the most recent developments at the crossroads of geometry and dynamical systems, with a special focus on integrable systems and applications to mathematical physics. The notion of integrable system in classical mechanics dates back to Joseph Liouville (1809-1882) and has an illustrious and long history. The modern resurgence of activity was initiated by the analysis of soliton solutions of nonlinear wave equations like the Korteweg deVries and Kadomtsev-Petviashvili equations. The conference aims to bring together both leading mathematicians that have contributed and are contributing to the success and dissemination of methods and ideas originating from integrable systems in all areas of mathematics and physics and also junior researchers and graduate students who should take over the lead in this fascinating field in the near future.<br/><br/>The renewed interest in integrable systems brought along the invention and development of far reaching solution techniques, including the inverse scattering method and the Sato-Segal-Wilson theory of infinite Grassmannians. The notion of integrable systems has since expanded considerably and often refers to a wide range of techniques. The development of techniques and new classes of integrable models has both cross-fertilized and received input from distant areas of mathematics and physics. There will be two types of presentations: (i) 25-30 plenary talks by leading specialists in the fields of geometry, dynamics, and integrability. (ii) Poster session mostly for young researchers working in the fields, with 10 minutes introductory oral presentation for each of them. The scientific background of the conference is based on relationships between several popular areas of research. Thus, it has a potential to attract young mathematicians, minorities and women to participate in exciting cross-disciplinary research and look for new applications of their research in other fields of science. The results of this event will be disseminated by the participants from around the world. https://indico.sissa.it/event/41/<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this NSF grant was to support the US based junior researchers to take part in the Conference Integrable Systems in Geometry and Mathematical Physics.

The Conference Integrable Systems in Geometry and Mathematical Physics was planned to be organized at SISSA, Trieste, Italy, July 13-17, 2020 as an in-person meeting. It was a satellite event to the Eight European Congress of Mathematics. The development of techniques and new classes of integrable models has both cross-fertilized and received input from distant areas of mathematics and physics. The conference aims at bringing together both leading mathematicians that have contributed and are contributing to the success and dissemination of methods and ideas originating from integrable systems in all areas of mathematics and physics and also junior researchers and graduate students who should take over the lead in this fascinating field in the near future. 

The scientific background of the Conference is based on relationships between several popular areas of research. Thus, it has had a potential to attract young mathematicians,  minorities and women to participate in exciting cross-disciplinary research and look for new applications of their research in other fields of science.

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Conference Integrable Systems in Geometry and Mathematical Physics, which was originally planned to be organized at SISSA, Trieste, Italy, in person in Summer of 2020, got postponed for Summer 2021. It was organized in a virtual format at SISSA, Trieste, Italy from June 28 till July 2, 2021: https://indico.sissa.it/event/41/.

Despite the delay of one year and the change of the format, the Conference managed to get together a quite impressive list of invited speakers: Anne Boutet de Monvel (Paris VI, France), Gaetan Borot (Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin), Alexander Buryak (Leeds University, UK), Mattia Cafasso (University of Angers, France), Mauro Carfora (University of  Pavia, Italy), Guido Carlet (Institut de Mathématiques de Bourgogne, Dijon, France), Tom Claeys (UCLouvain, Belgium), Vladimir Dragovic (UT Dallas, USA),Yakov Eliashberg (Stanford  University, USA), Gregorio Falqui (Milano Bicocca, Italy), Giovanni Felder  (ETH Zurich, Switzerland), Evgeny Ferapontov (Loughborough  University, UK), Alexander Givental (University of California Berkeley, USA), Claus Hertling (Mannheim University, Germany), Alexander R. Its (Indiana University-Purdue University, USA), Nalini Joshi (University of Sydney, Australia), Christian Klein (Institut de Mathématiques de Bourgogne, Dijon, France), Dmitry Korotkin (Concordia University, Montreal, CANADA), Igor Krichever (Columbia University,  New York,  USA), Arno Kuijlaars  (KU Leuven, Belgium), Oleg Lisovyy (University of Tours, France),  Marta Mazzocco (Birmingham University, UK), Ken McLaughlin (Colorado State University, Fort Collins, USA), Andrei Okounkov (Columbia University,  New York, USA), Vasilisa Shramchenko (Sherbrooke University , CA), Ian Strachan (Glasgow  University,  UK), Alexander Veselov (Loughborough  University, UK),  Di Yang (University Science and Technology of China, China), Don Zagier (ICTP, Trieste Italy and Max Planck Bonn, Germany), Youjin Zhang (Tsinghua  University, China).

In order to support more junior participants, the Organizers provided also a virtual poster session with the possibility for each participant to present their poster in a 3-minute oral presentations for the entire body of participants. There were 22 poster presentations accompanied each with a 3-minute oral presentation.

There were four female plenary speakers and six female poster presenters.

 There were 237 registered participants.

In addition to that, the funds from this NSF grant were used to support participants from the U.S.,  to attend in person the following conference with a similar scientific scope and in a similar geographic area, as originally planned for the Conference Integrable Systems in Geometry and Mathematical Physics :

The Eight International Conference Geometry, Dynamics, Integrable Systems GDIS 2022, June 5-11, 2022, Zlatibor, Serbia,

http://www.mi.sanu.ac.rs/~gdis2022/.

There were 33 invited plenary talks and the poster session. The conference was held in a hybrid format due to the pandemic, but the organizers managed to get it implemented mostly in in-person modality. Out of 33 invited plenary lectures, 29 were delivered in-person and four online. Five plenary lecturers were female.

For many, that was the first in-person event after winter 2020 and the start of the pandemic. The conference gathered specialists from 14 countries.

The poster session provided platform for advanced graduate students and junior researchers to present their work. This created  an opportunity for them  to obtain feedback from senior experts. The networking activities through the conference and ample social activities were an important experience not only for young researchers but for all participants. This was especially emphasized by the dominant in-person nature of the conference, immediately after the long period of isolation caused by the COVID 19 pandemic.

The feedback gathered by the organizers from the participants of both conferences, Integrable Systems in Geometry and Mathematical Physics from 2021 and Geometry, Dynamics, Integrable Systems GDIS 2022 were all extremely positive. This includes the feedback from the US based researchers supported by this NSF grant.
